CHAPTER LXIII.

OF COPPER.

CoPPER'is engendered in the earth. When a vein of which is found, it is acquired with the greatest labour by digging and breaking. It is a stone of a green colour, and most hard and naturally mixed with lead. This stone, dug up in abund- ance, is placed upon a pile and burned, after the manner of chalk, nor does it change colour, but yet loses its hardness, so that it can be broken up. Then, being bruised small, it is placed in the furnace; coals and the bellows being applied, it is in- cessantly forged by day and night.
